title: Contributing to nycOpenData

title: Contributing to nycOpenData

Whether issue intermittent (likely related rate limits timeouts).

title: Using Local Law18 Pay Report

R, nycOpenData package can used pull data directly. nycOpenData package provides streamlined interface accessing New York City‚Äôs vast open data resources. connects directly NYC Open Data Portal. currently utilized primary tool teaching data acquisition Reproducible Research Using R, helping students bridge gap raw city APIs tidy data analysis. using nyc_locallaw18_payreport function, can gather recent statistics Local Law 18 filter based upon columns inside dataset. Note: nyc_locallaw18_payreport automatically sorts descending order based created_date column.

title: Using Local Law18 Pay Report

A tibble: 3 √ó 11 #>   data_year agency_name         eeo_4_job_category pay_band lower_pay_band_bound #>   <chr>     <chr>               <chr>              <chr>    <chr>                #> 1 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        95000-9‚Ä¶ 95000                #> 2 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        85000-8‚Ä¶ 85000                #> 3 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        85000-8‚Ä¶ 85000                #> # ‚Ñπ 6 more variables: upper_pay_band_bound <chr>, employee_status <chr>, #> #   race <chr>, ethnicity <chr>, gender <chr>, number_of_employees <chr>   # Checking to see the filtering worked unique(lessthan5_locallaw18payreport) #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 11 #>   data_year agency_name         eeo_4_job_category pay_band lower_pay_band_bound #>   <chr>     <chr>               <chr>              <chr>    <chr>                #> 1 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        95000-9‚Ä¶ 95000                #> 2 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        85000-8‚Ä¶ 85000                #> 3 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        85000-8‚Ä¶ 85000                #> # Calling head of our new dataset head(lessthan5TI_payreport) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 11 #>   data_year agency_name         eeo_4_job_category pay_band lower_pay_band_bound #>   <chr>     <chr>               <chr>              <chr>    <chr>                #> 1 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        95000-9‚Ä¶ 95000                #> 2 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        85000-8‚Ä¶ 85000                #> 3 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        65000-6‚Ä¶ 65000                #> 4 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        55000-5‚Ä¶ 55000                #> 5 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        55000-5‚Ä¶ 55000                #> 6 2022      TECHNOLOGY & INNOV‚Ä¶ TECHNICIANS        50000-5‚Ä¶ 50000                #> # ‚Ñπ 6 more variables: upper_pay_band_bound <chr>, employee_status <chr>, #> #   race <chr>, ethnicity <chr>, gender <chr>, number_of_employees <chr>  # Quick check to make sure our filtering worked nrow(lessthan5TI_payreport) #> [1] 15 unique(lessthan5TI_payreport$agency_name) #> [1] "TECHNOLOGY & INNOVATION" unique(lessthan5TI_payreport$gender) #> [1] "Female"

title: Using Local Law18 Pay Report
text: Now successfully pulled data R, let‚Äôs mini analysis, using ethnicity column, figure ethnicity aforementioned groups. , create bar graph ethnicities. Bar chart showing ethnicity female workers municipal departments less 5 people Technology & Innovation (15 recent. graph shows us many rows bracket Technology & Information/>5 employees/female, ethnicities workers .
code: # Visualizing the distribution, ordered by frequency  lessthan5TI_payreport %>%   count(ethnicity) %>%          # count how many rows fall in each ethnicity   ggplot(aes(     x = n,                       # n = number of rows per ethnicity     y = reorder(ethnicity, n)    # reorder ethnicities by their counts   )) +   geom_col(fill = "steelblue") + # geom_col uses the counts we already computed   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Ethnicity of Female Employees in Bracket of TI Agencies with Fewer Than 5 Employees",     subtitle = "Most Recent 15 Records",     x = "Number of Records",     y = "Ethnicity"   )

title: Summary
text: New York City maintains one comprehensive open data portals world. However, researchers students often face barriers accessing data, including navigating diverse endpoint identifiers, managing API rate limits, cleaning raw JSON responses. general-purpose Socrata wrappers exist, require users manually specify API endpoints handle domain-specific data types. nycOpenData addresses challenges providing curated wrappers high-impact datasets used urban research. package currently core pedagogical component curriculum ‚ÄòReproducible Research Using R‚Äô, serves primary tool teaching automated data acquisition. 500 downloads date, package demonstrated significant utility academic practitioner environments.

title: Summary
text: Curated Access: Wrappers 40+ datasets including TLC records, crime statistics, environmental data. Reproducibility: Integrated vcr package mocked HTTP testing, allowing research pipelines verified offline. Tidy Format: Every function ensures date-time strings, numeric values, logical flags correctly parsed R types upon arrival.
